LineAnalysis.content: Your personal chronicle for tabletop adventures
Create rich settings with locations, NPCs, and lore
Document adventures and never forget what happened
Let AI help you remember the important details
Your content is organized in a hierarchy that mirrors how tabletop campaigns work.
Your campaign setting â€” the universe where your adventures take place.
This could be an official setting like Forgotten Realms or Eberron,
or your own homebrew creation. Everything else lives inside a World.
A specific adventure or ongoing game with your group. You might run
Curse of Strahd and Tomb of Annihilation in the same world â€”
those would be two separate campaigns. Each campaign tracks its own story.
Story chapters within a campaign. Maybe your party spent several sessions
in Waterdeep, then traveled to Baldur's Gate â€” those could be separate arcs.
Arcs help you organize sessions into meaningful chunks.
A single game night. Each session belongs to an arc and captures what
happened during that play session â€” encounters, discoveries, memorable moments.
Each world has four main sections in the sidebar to organize your content.
Where your game sessions live. Create campaigns, add arcs to organize
the story, then log sessions as you play. This is your adventure timeline.
Tip: After each session, jot down key events, NPCs met,
and decisions made. Future you will thank present you.
Home for player characters in your group. Create a character articles on the World Detail page,
then claim it as yours to see it on your dashboard.
Track backstory, goals, relationships, and growth.
Tip: Link your character to NPCs and locations using
[[wiki links]] to build a web of connections.
Your world-building encyclopedia. Document locations, NPCs, factions,
items, lore, religions, history â€” anything that makes your world feel alive.
Nest articles to create hierarchies (e.g., Continent â†’ Region â†’ City â†’ District).
Tip: Use the AI Summary feature on articles with lots of
Quick links to tools your group uses â€” D&D Beyond character sheets,
Roll20 or Foundry VTT, shared Google Drives, Discord servers.
Plus, upload documents like character sheets, maps, handouts, and reference
materials (PDFs, Office files, images up to 200MB) to keep everything in one place.
Tip: Only the world owner can upload and manage documents,
but all members can download them.
Here's how to get the most out of Chronicis:
Type [[Article Name]] to create links between articles.
This builds a connected knowledge base.
Open your character article and click "Claim as My Character"
to see it on your dashboard.
Articles with backlinks can generate AI summaries.
Click the summary button in the article sidebar.
Ctrl+S to save, Ctrl+N to create a new article.
Your work also auto-saves as you type.
Drag articles in the sidebar to reorganize your hierarchy.
Nest content however makes sense for your world.
Make your world public in World Settings to share it with anyone
via a custom URLâ€”no login required for viewers.
Toggle any article to private in the metadata panel.
Only you can see private articlesâ€”perfect for DM notes or plot twists.
Click the help icon in the top bar anytime to return to this guide.
